bibl.title: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, October 4, 1924

div1.p: LePrince reports on the malaria exhibit in Memphis, Tennessee. He mentions a malaria census in Shelby County, Tennessee.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, October 4, 1924
div1.opener:
Oct 4/24
malaria
Deeks-
Dear Dr Carter
div1.p:
Your letter relative to Dr Deeks
problems was forwarded on to me &
I wrote out my ideas and sent them
on to be typed & sent on to you-

Dr Deeks kindly sent me copy of letter
he sent you so I know you received
the hurried notes I sent you- Then

Things are going well at present-
I have been out in the field all Summer
excepting the Jamaica trip and three days
at Headquarters since July 4th - got back
this week-. The inspector at Savannah
P. H. Smith says he used (quicklime) powdered
to float his Paris green in dust cloud
in place of road dust & that it
killed both culex & anopheles
larvae - am having this checked to
see if it is so-. Its too good to be true.

The malaria exhibit at the Tri
state Agr. Fair, Memphis was a
huge success & as I was not present
(2
& did not even see it - so much the
better - they are not leaving on us -
but stand on their own legs- It
pleases me particularly because the
initiative comes from the county
sanitary inspector- The only way
in which I am involved is that I selected
the inspector two years ago-

He has taken a malaria census
of Shelby County Tenn - got a line
on volunteered malaria census of 68%
of rural population (white) & about
some for colored - by School Districts-
so he has relative amount of malaria
by geographical divisions of county
ie (school districts) the white census
cost less than $20.00 to obtain

One of the census cards that came back
was properly filled out & had written
across its face in red ink
“This is Pure Graft”
3
Dr L L Williams Jr has got the county
health officers in Virginia interested in
malaria control to the extent that some
of those formerly “luke warm” are using
hip boots & wading out into the ponds
to collect larvae & breed them out &
recording their findings-

Its quite different from the man
we met at Columbus Ga ten years
ago-.

I had some models “a foot long”
of anopheles larvae & pupae made
to use at exhibits, county fairs, etc

Dr Coogle is making some new
“Moth balls” - big ones - made of
Naptha, Camphor, & (distillation
biproducts from creosote manufacture),
that They evaporate slowly, the smell
is not objectionable to humans but
its “pizen” to “anopheles nostrels” or
skeeter noses-
